title: Future Forms: Will, Be Going To, Present Continuous
summary: This lesson explains the different ways to talk about the future in English using 'will', 'be going to', the present continuous, and other forms such as 'may' and 'might'.
content: 'Will' is used for predictions, instant decisions, offers, promises, and future facts.
'Be going to' is used for intentions, plans, predictions based on evidence, and future arrangements.
The present continuous is used for fixed future arrangements when the time is mentioned.
The present simple is used for future time clauses with words like 'when', 'as soon as', 'until', 'before', and 'after'.
'May' and 'might' are used to talk about possible future actions or events when we are uncertain.

examples.rule: Use 'will' for predictions or future facts.
examples: I think he’ll win the election.
He will be a good doctor.
The president will visit the Vatican next November.

examples.rule: Use 'be going to' for near-future predictions based on evidence.
examples: Don’t drive like a crazy man. We’re going to have an accident!
The doctor said I’m going to have a girl.
‘Oh, we don’t have sugar.’ ‘Don’t worry, I’ll buy some.’

examples.rule: Use 'be going to' for planned decisions or intentions.
examples: ‘Why are you undressing?’ ‘Because I’m going to go to the swimming pool.’

examples.rule: Use present continuous for future arrangements with a time expression.
examples: I’m seeing the dentist at 6.
We are getting married next week.
I’m flying to New York tomorrow morning.

examples.rule: You can also use 'be going to' for future arrangements.
examples: I’m going to play tennis with Elisabeth today.

examples.rule: Use present simple for future time clauses (when, as soon as, until, before, after).
examples: I’ll retire when I’m 70.
I won’t call you until I arrive.

examples.rule: Use 'will' for promises, refusals, offers, suggestions, and requests.
examples: I will help you whenever you need me.
I won’t lend him my car.
I’ll carry that bag for you.
Shall we eat out today?
Will you open the door, please?

examples.rule: Use 'may' or 'might' for uncertain future possibilities.
examples: I might be late for dinner today.
I might go to Denmark next September.
The economy might suffer a global recession next year.
Temperatures may go up next week.
She might not come with us.
We may not have enough time to finish the report for tomorrow.

tips: Use 'will' when making instant decisions, promises, or talking about facts.
'Be going to' expresses planned decisions and predictions based on present evidence.
Always include a time expression when using the present continuous for future arrangements.
In time clauses about the future, use the present simple, not 'will'.
'May' and 'might' are great for expressing uncertainty or possible outcomes.
